page.title: 11TOURISM IN GREAT AYTON
page.content:
Many people go to the Low Green on a Sunday afternoon where their children can safely paddle in the River Leven. The cross bred Mallard ducks and their ducklings are an attraction in early summer. The Buck Hotel is opposite Low Green and has recently been adapted to cater for families, providing meals as well as continental style outdoor tables. The Norman All Saints Church attracts some tourists. Many Australians visit Great Ayton because of its connection with Captain James Cook: an obelisk in a garden marks the former site of his parents' cottage, removed to Melbourne in 1934.
There is a successful and popular Caravan Club listed site on the north-west edge of the village.
